heif

Class BoxHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • heif.BoxHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ImageHandler, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.lang.Iterable<Box>

    public class BoxHandler
extends java.lang.Object
implements ImageHandler, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.lang.Iterable<Box>
    Handles parsing of HEIF/HEIC file structures based on the ISO Base Media Format.

    Supports Exif/XMP extraction, box navigation, and hierarchical parsing.

    API Note: According to HEIF/HEIC standards, some box types are optional and may appear zero or one time per file.

    Thread Safety: This class is not thread-safe as it maintains internal state of the underlying ByteStreamReader.

    Since:
    13 August 2025
    Version:
    1.1
    Author:
    Trevor Maggs

    • Constructor Detail

      • BoxHandler

        public BoxHandler(java.nio.file.Path fpath)
           throws java.io.IOException
        Constructs a BoxHandler to open the specified file for the parsing of the embedded metadata, honouring the big-endian byte order in accordance with the ISO/IEC 14496-12 documentation.

        Note: This constructor opens a file-based resource. The handler should be used within a try-with-resources block to ensure the file lock is released.

        Parameters:
        fpath - to open the image file for parsing
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file cannot be accessed or an I/O error occurs

    • Method Detail

      • close

        public void close()
           throws java.io.IOException
        Closes the underlying ByteStreamReader resource.
        Specified by:
        close in interface java.lang.AutoCloseable
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • parseMetadata

        public boolean parseMetadata()
                      throws java.io.IOException
        Parses all HEIF boxes from the stream and builds the internal box tree structure, necessary to extract metadata from the HEIF container.

        This method skips un-handled types such as mdat and gracefully recovers from malformed boxes using a fail-fast approach.

        After calling this method, you can retrieve the extracted metadata segment (if present) by invoking getExifData() or getXmpData().

        Specified by:
        parseMetadata in interface ImageHandler
        Returns:
        true if at least one HEIF box was successfully extracted, or false if no relevant boxes were found
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<Box> iterator()
        Returns a depth-first iterator over all parsed boxes, starting from root boxes.

        The iteration respects the hierarchy of boxes, processing children before siblings (depth-first traversal).

        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<Box>
        Returns:
        an Iterator for recursively visiting all boxes

      • getExifData

        public java.util.Optional<byte[]> getExifData()
                                       throws java.io.IOException
        Extracts the embedded Exif TIFF block linked to the primary image within the HEIF container.

        This method correctly implements the resolution of Exif items by:

        1. Identifying the Exif Item ID via findMetadataID(MetadataType).
        2. Retrieving the full payload (supporting fragmented extents).
        3. Stripping any legacy JPEG 'Exif\0\0' preambles.
        4. Calculating the physical shift to the TIFF Header (II/MM magic bytes) as per ISO/IEC 23008-12:2017 Annex A.
        Returns:
        an Optional containing the TIFF-compatible Exif block (starting at the Byte Order Mark), or Optional.empty() if no valid Exif is found
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the payload cannot be computed due to an I/O error

      • getXmpData

        public java.util.Optional<byte[]> getXmpData()
                                      throws java.io.IOException
        Extracts the raw XMP metadata entries from the HEIF container. Note: XMP is typically raw UTF-8 XML without the 4-byte HEIF header that is the case for Exif.
        Returns:
        an Optional containing the XMP bytes, or Optional.empty() if not found
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if reading the file fails

      • getThumbnailData

        public java.util.Optional<byte[]> getThumbnailData()
                                            throws java.io.IOException
        Extracts the thumbnail image bytes linked to the primary image.
        Returns:
        an Optional containing the raw image bytes (often JPEG), or Optional.empty() if no thumbnail is linked
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs during extraction

      • findMetadataID

        public int findMetadataID(BoxHandler.MetadataType type)
        Retrieves the ID of a specific metadata segment (i.e. Exif or XMP) linked to the primary image.

        Search Logic:

        1. Primary Linkage (Strict): Searches the Item Reference box (iref) for content describes (cdsc) references where the to_item_ID is the Primary Item ID.
        2. Validation: If the required reference is identified, verifies the item type in iinf. If XMP exists, it further validates the content type is application/rdf+xml as per ISO/IEC 23008-12.
        3. Fallback: If no explicit reference exists in iref, performs a type-based global scan of the Item Information box (iinf). It may be less accurate.
        Parameters:
        type - the metadata type to find
        Returns:
        the item_id of the metadata, or -1 if not found

      • getPhysicalAddress

        public long getPhysicalAddress(int itemID,
                               long logicalOffset,
                               BoxHandler.MetadataType type)
                        throws java.io.IOException
        Translates a logical offset within a metadata item into an absolute physical file position.

        Fragmented Items: HEIF allows a single item (like an Exif block) to be split across multiple non-contiguous physical sections called . This method traverses the iloc (Item Location) box to map the logical logicalOffset to the correct physical extent.

        Parameters:
        itemID - the HEIF item ID
        logicalOffset - the offset relative to the start of the item's data
        type - the metadata type (used to calculate TIFF preamble shifts)
        Returns:
        the absolute byte position in the file, or -1 if the mapping fails
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the underlying box data cannot be accessed

      • walkBoxes

        private void walkBoxes(Box box,
                       int depth)
        Recursively traverses the HEIF box tree to build the internal map and establish parent-child relationships.

        Each encountered box is indexed by its type and assigned its depth within the hierarchy for diagnostic purposes. Must be called internally by the parseMetadata() method.

        Parameters:
        box - the box to process and index
        depth - the current structural level within the ISOBMFF hierarchy

      • getRawBytes

        private byte[] getRawBytes(int itemID)
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Extracts raw bytes from fragmented data extents belonging to the specified Item ID. This also supports both Construction Method 0 (Offset) and Construction Method 1 (IDAT) automatically.
        Parameters:
        itemID - the ID of the item (Exif or XMP)
        Returns:
        a byte array containing the raw data identified with the specified ID
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • readExtent

        private byte[] readExtent(int constructionMethod,
                          ItemLocationBox.ExtentData extent)
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Reads a specific extent of data from the underlying data source based on the item's specified construction method.

        This method implements the data retrieval logic defined in ISO/IEC 14496-12:

        • Method 0 (File Offset): Data is stored at an absolute position within the file (standard for mdat boxes).
        • Method 1 (IDAT Relative): Data is stored within the idat box payload. The offset is relative to the start of the idat data.
        Parameters:
        constructionMethod - the identifier (0 or 1) indicating how to interpret the extent offset
        extent - the ItemLocationBox.ExtentData containing the specific length and offset for this fragment
        Returns:
        a byte array containing the raw data for the specified extent
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if Method 1 is specified but no idat box exists, or if the requested range is out of bounds (corrupt iloc table)

      • isXmpType

        private boolean isXmpType(ItemInfoEntry infe)
        For the specified infe entry associated with the MIME type, it validates if this corresponds to XMP data by checking its content type matching with either of the following identifiers.
        • application/rdf+xml - usually Apple (iPhone)
        • application/x-adobe-xmp - potentially Android/Samsung
        • text/xml - also potentially Android/Samsung or maybe ImageMagick/GPAC
        Parameters:
        infe - the reference to the ItemInfoEntry resource
        Returns:
        boolean true if the entry contains the valid content type in relation to XMP metadata

      • getBox

        private <T extends Box> T getBox(HeifBoxType type,
                                 java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
        Retrieves the first matching box of a specific type and class.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the generic box type
        Parameters:
        type - the box type identifier
        clazz - the expected box class
        Returns:
        the matching box, or null if not present or of the wrong type
